name.text: Finding the reduced row echelon form of a matrix

questiontext.text:
Find the reduced row echelon form of the matrix \(A\).

\(A={@matrix_A@}\)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Step1: Here, the left most nonzero entry is in the second column.

Step2: By swapping row \(1\) with row \(3\) , we can obtain the pivot position as follows:

\({@matrix_A@} R_{1}\leftrightarrow R_{3} {@matrix_1@}\)

Step 3: Now the leading entry is \(1\), and to create zeros in all positions below the pivot, we use the replacement rule:

\(R_{2}\rightarrow R_{2}+(-{@aa@})R_{1} {@matrix_2@}\)

Step 4: Now we proceed to the second row. Here, the leading entry is \(âˆ’2\). Using a scaling rule we obtain a leading \(1\):

\(R_{2}\rightarrow ({@ww@})R_{2} {@matrix_3@}\)

And applying row replacement rule:

\(R_{3}\rightarrow R_{3}+({@ww_1@})R_{2} {@matrix_4@}\)

And scaling \(R_{3},\)

\(R_{3}\leftrightarrow ({@ww_4@})R_{3}{@matrix_5@}\)

Step 5: Beginning with the rightmost pivot column, we create zeros above each pivot element. That is, we start from the fourth column:

\(R_{1}\rightarrow R_{1}+({@-ee@})R_{3},R_{2}\rightarrow R_{2}+({@ww_7@})R_{3}{@matrix_6@}\)

And using row replacement (to create zeros above the pivot element in the third column),

\(R_{1}\rightarrow R_{1}+({@ww_8@})R_{2}{@matrix_7@}\)

Thus, the required matrix in reduced row echelon form is given by

\({@ta@}\)
